elements.content: The π-contact hypothesis, that quenching of the fluorescence of complexes of photoinduced electron transfer sensors with heavy diamagnetic metal ions may be caused by π contacts between the metal ion and the fluorophore of the sensor, is examined with a study of the fluorescent properties of the sensor 4-[[bis­(2-pyridinylmethyl)­amino]­methyl]-6,7-dimethoxy-1-benzopyran-2-one (cdpa) and the structures of its complexes with some metal ions. The coumarin-type fluorophore of cdpa is a weaker π-contact former than the anthracenyl fluorophore of the analogue adpa (Inorg. Chem. 2014, 53, 9014): only AgI, the strongest π contact former, quenches the fluorescence of cdpa, apart from paramagnetic CuII and NiII, which quench fluorescence by a redox mechanism not requiring π contacts. The structures of [Ag­(cdpa)­NO3] (1), [Pb­(cdpa)­(NO3)2] (2), [Zn­(cdpa)­(NO3)2] (3), [Cd­(cdpa)­Cl2]2 (4), [Cd­(cdpa)2H2O]­(NO3)2 (5), and [Hg­(cdpa)2H2O]­(NO3)2 (6) are reported. Structure 1 shows that AgI is the only metal ion studied that forms π contacts with the fluorophore of cdpa in the solid state: Ag···C η2 π contacts of 3.083 and 3.095 Å, in line with quenching of the fluorescence of the AgI(cdpa) complex. In contrast, PbII, ZnII, and CdII show chelation-enhanced fluorescence in their cdpa complexes, and the structures of 2–4 show that the fluorophore of cdpa in each case forms no π contacts. By contrast, the adpa complexes of PbII and CdII show π contacts with its more strongly π-contacting fluorophore (Inorg. Chem. 2014, 53, 9014). The structures of 5 and 6 show bis-complexes of cdpa: the coordination geometries of CdII and HgII are discussed in relation to the number of covalently bound donor atoms present. The preferred hapticity of π-contacted metal ions is evaluated from the literature structures, suggesting that d10 metal ions such as AgI and HgII, and tetragonally distorted CuII and PdII, prefer η1 and η2 π contacts, while more ionically bound metal ions such as KI, BaII, and LaIII, as well as d10s2 metal ions such as TlI, PbII, and BiIII, prefer η6 contacts.

elements.content: The π-contact hypothesis, that quenching of the fluorescence of photoinduced electron transfer sensors by heavy diamagnetic metal ions is largely caused by π contacts between the metal ion and fluorophore, is examined. The coumarin-type fluorophore of 4-[[bis­(2-pyridinylmethyl)­amino]­methyl]-6,7-dimethoxy-1-benzopyran-2-one (cdpa) is a weaker π contacter than the anthracenyl fluorophore of the analogue adpa: only AgI quenches the fluorescence of cdpa. Structures show that AgI is also the only metal ion studied that forms π contacts with the fluorophore of cdpa: PbII, ZnII, and CdII show chelation-enhanced fluorescence in their cdpa complexes, and their structures show that the fluorophore of cdpa in each case forms no π contacts.

The coumarin-type fluorophore of 4-[[bis(2-pyridinylmethyl)amino]methyl]-6,7-dimethoxy-1-benzopyran-2-one (cdpa) is a weaker π contacter than the anthracenyl fluorophore of the analogue adpa: only AgI quenches the fluorescence of cdpa. Structures show that AgI is also the only metal ion studied that forms π contacts with the fluorophore of cdpa: PbII, ZnII, and CdII show chelation-enhanced fluorescence in their cdpa complexes, and their structures show that the fluorophore of cdpa in each case forms no π contacts.

elements.content: In previous work, it was shown crystallographically that there are π contacts between heavy diamagnetic metal ions such as HgII, PbII, AgI, and PdII complexed by adpa and the anthracenyl fluorophore of the sensor (see for abbreviations of ligands or sensors discussed in this paper). It was suggested, as supported by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, that π contacts with metal ions were mainly responsible for quenching of the fluorescence of such photoinduced electron transfer (PET) sensors in solution. Such quenching of the fluorescence is widely regarded as being due to large spin–orbit coupling constants (ζ), which stabilize the triplet state and so promote the nonradiative return of the excited electron to the ground state. In contrast to the adpa complexes of the above heavy elements, the structure of the ZnII(adpa) complex shows no π contacts: there is a corresponding large increase in the fluorescence intensity of its adpa complex compared with the adpa free ligand, a chelation-enhanced fluorescence (CHEF) effect. CdII is borderline between the metal ions that π-contact strongly, such as HgII, PbII, AgI, and PdII, and ZnII, which π-contacts only weakly, if at all, in solution. CdII thus shows a weaker CHEF effect than does ZnII, which was suggested to be due to the CdII(adpa) complex existing in solution as an equilibrium mixture of a π-contacted form (weakly fluorescent) and a non-π-contacted form (strongly fluorescent). The π-contact model of fluorescence quenching suggests that a second ligand might bind to the CdII(adpa) complex and weaken or disrupt the π contact that is quenching the fluorescence. This leads to a new type of fluorescence sensor, where there is a large shift to shorter wavelength and an increase in the fluorescence intensity when Cl–, Br–, SCN–, or S2O3 2– bind to the CdII(adpa) complex. The π-contact model also predicts that with a more weakly π-contacting fluorophore, the CdII complex may not be strongly π-contacted in solution, and then there would be much less of a fluorescent response to added anions.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

In previous work, it was shown crystallographically that there are π contacts between heavy diamagnetic metal ions such as HgII, PbII, AgI, and PdII complexed by adpa and the anthracenyl fluorophore of the sensor (see  for abbreviations of ligands or sensors discussed in this paper). It was suggested, as supported by density functional theory (DFT) calculations, that π contacts with metal ions were mainly responsible for quenching of the fluorescence of such photoinduced electron transfer (PET) sensors in solution. Such quenching of the fluorescence is widely regarded as being due to large spin-orbit coupling constants (ζ), which stabilize the triplet state and so promote the nonradiative return of the excited electron to the ground state. In contrast to the adpa complexes of the above heavy elements, the structure of the ZnII(adpa) complex shows no π contacts: there is a corresponding large increase in the fluorescence intensity of its adpa complex compared with the adpa free ligand, a chelation-enhanced fluorescence (CHEF) effect. CdII is borderline between the metal ions that π-contact strongly, such as HgII, PbII, AgI, and PdII, and ZnII, which π-contacts only weakly, if at all, in solution. CdII thus shows a weaker CHEF effect than does ZnII, which was suggested to be due to the CdII(adpa) complex existing in solution as an equilibrium mixture of a π-contacted form (weakly fluorescent) and a non-π-contacted form (strongly fluorescent). The π-contact model of fluorescence quenching suggests that a second ligand might bind to the CdII(adpa) complex and weaken or disrupt the π contact that is quenching the fluorescence. This leads to a new type of fluorescence sensor, where there is a large shift to shorter wavelength and an increase in the fluorescence intensity when Cl-, Br-, SCN-, or S2O3 2- bind to the CdII(adpa) complex. The π-contact model also predicts that with a more weakly π-contacting fluorophore, the CdII complex may not be strongly π-contacted in solution, and then there would be much less of a fluorescent response to added anions.

elements.content: The idea that π contacts might be responsible for quenching of the fluorescence has also been explored by Ojida et al., who have reported the fluorescence properties of metal-ion complexes of dadpa (). Crystal structures demonstrate the presence of a π-contact between AgI and the anthracenyl fluorophore of dadpa, so that AgI quenches the fluorescence of dadpa. Hitomi et al. have shown that disruption of the Ag···C π contact with the anthracenyl fluorophore of the ligand an10-NS2 by coordinating ethylene allows for the AgI(an10-NS2) complex to act as a fluorescent sensor for ethylene and other alkenes.
elements.clean_text: The idea that π contacts might be responsible for quenching of the fluorescence has also been explored by Ojida et al., who have reported the fluorescence properties of metal-ion complexes of dadpa (). Crystal structures demonstrate the presence of a π-contact between AgI and the anthracenyl fluorophore of dadpa, so that AgI quenches the fluorescence of dadpa. Hitomi et al. have shown that disruption of the Ag⋅⋅⋅C π contact with the anthracenyl fluorophore of the ligand an10-NS2 by coordinating ethylene allows for the AgI(an10-NS2) complex to act as a fluorescent sensor for ethylene and other alkenes.

elements.content: In order to further investigate the π-contact model of quenching of the fluorescent PET sensors, it would be informative to investigate fluorophores that differ from anthracene in their metal π-contact forming ability. Gokel et al. have used electrostatic potential maps, computed for fluorophores using wave-mechanical calculations, to indicate the metal π-contact forming ability; fluorophores with higher electron density in their π systems should be better π-contact formers. In are shown the electrostatic potential maps for naphthalene (which should be similar to anthracene) and coumarin, showing that coumarin has a lower electron density in its π system than does naphthalene and should therefore be a weaker π-contacter. The synthesis of a coumarin-based sensor, 4-[[bis­(2-pyridinylmethyl)­amino]­methyl]-6,7-dimethoxy-1-benzopyran-2-one (cdpa) in , and an extensive study of its fluorescence properties with some metal ions have already been reported by Lim and Bruckner. The focus here will be on cdpa and the relationship between the occurrence of π contacts in cdpa complexes and of its fluorescence properties with metal ions. Judging from the frequency of occurrence of π-contacted structures in the CSD, as well as DFT calculations, the order of the π-contacting ability of the metal ions considered here is NiII ≈ ZnII ≪ CdII < PbII < HgII < PdII ≈ CuII ≈ AgI. This is not an ordering of the absolute strength of π-contact formation but includes the ease of displacement of a competing solvent molecule or other ligand by the aromatic group that forms the π contact. In solution, the ability to form π contacts appears to be related to low solvation energies, so that such an ability is favored by metal ions of lower charge, particularly alkali-metal ions, TlI and AgI. Because anthracene is a strong π-contact former, one finds that all of the above metal ions cluster together to form π contacts with adpa in solution, with only ZnII and NiII not forming a π contact and the intermediate CdII displaying structures with and without π contacts. With a weaker π-contact former such as the dimethoxycoumarin fluorophore of cdpa, one expects the presence of π-contacted structures to be spread out, with a consequently greater ability to display a CHEF effect moving along the π-contacting strength series toward AgI, the most able π-contact former of those metal ions considered here. In other words, the weak π-contacter cdpa should make more apparent the above order of the π-contacting ability of metal ions, where the strong π-contacter adpa somewhat masks the order by π-contacting with all of the metal ions studied except for ZnII.

elements.content: Electrostatic potential maps calculated using DFT (B3LYP 6-31G**) for (a) naphthalene and (b) coumarin. Red color = more negative electron density. Green to deep blue = more positive electron density. The more yellow color of the naphthalene π cloud suggests that naphthalene, and also anthracene, should be a stronger π-contact former with metal ions than coumarin. Maps plotted using the program Spartan.

elements.content: An important aspect of quenching of the fluorescence of sensors such as adpa is distortion of the coordination geometry around heavy d10 metal ions such as AgI or HgII. For these heavy d10 ions with a set of donor atoms that include both covalently and ionically bound donors, a quasi-linear structure is usually produced, with short M–N bonds to the two more covalently bound donors, in the case of adpa the sp2-hybridized N donors of the two pyridyl groups, which are placed at roughly 180° to each other. Long M–L bonds to the remaining donor atoms are found, which are placed at roughly right angles to the more covalently bound donors in the favored linear sites. Thus, long Hg–N bonds to the sp3-hybridized central N donor of adpa are produced. This means that, even when the Hg···C π contact that is thought to quench the fluorescence of the complex is disrupted by coordination of a halide, the poor orbital overlap between the Hg atom and the N donor from the long Hg–N bond still allows a PET effect: little increase in the fluorescence intensity is observed. In contrast, CdII has a much weaker tendency toward such distortion of its coordination sphere: binding of Cl–, Br–, SCN–, or S2O3 2– to CdII in its adpa complex weakens the Cd···C π contact that is quenching the fluorescence, the fluorescence intensity increases, and the CdII(adpa) complex can potentially act as a fluorescent sensor for the above anions. In this paper, the coordination geometry of heavy d10 metal ions and how the problem of distortion of the coordination geometry to produce long Hg–N or Ag–N bonds that lead to a PET effect and quenching of the fluorescence might be overcome are further considered.

elements.content: A study of the fluorescence of cdpa complexes is reported here, augmenting that reported for cdpa by Lim and Bruckner in methanol (MeOH). Our studies were carried out in 50% MeOH/H2O to make them comparable with our previous studies of adpa reported in the same solvent. This is necessitated by the sensitivity of the fluorescence results to the solvent, particularly its hydrogen-bonding ability. The π-contact forming abilities of the fluorophore of cdpa were investigated crystallographically in the complexes [Ag­(cdpa)­NO3] (1), [Pb­(cdpa)­(NO3)2] (2), [Zn­(cdpa)­(NO3)2] (3), [Cd­(cdpa)­Cl2]2 (4), [Cd­(cdpa)2H2O]­(NO3)2 (5), and [Hg­(cdpa)2H2O]­(NO3)2 (6) in order to relate these to the fluorescence properties of the complexes.

elements.content: The ligand 4-[[bis­(2-pyridinylmethyl)­amino]­methyl]-6,7-dimethoxy-1-benzopyran-2-one (cdpa) was synthesized following a literature method. The metal salts AgNO3 (Fisher), CdCl2·2.5H2O (Fisher), Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (Riedel-de Haen), Hg­(NO3)2·xH2O (Alfa Aesar), Pb­(NO3)2 (Fisher), and Zn­(NO3)2·6H2O (Aldrich) and metal perchlorates were obtained from VWR or Strem in ≥99% purity and used as received. All solutions were made up in deionized water (Milli-Q, Waters Corp.) of >18 MΩ·cm–1 resistivity, plus high-performance liquid chromatography grade methanol (MeOH) from Merck. Solutions were prepared in liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry grade MeOH and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

The ligand 4-[[bis(2-pyridinylmethyl)amino]methyl]-6,7-dimethoxy-1-benzopyran-2-one (cdpa) was synthesized following a literature method. The metal salts AgNO3 (Fisher), CdCl2⋅2.5H2O (Fisher), Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (Riedel-de Haen), Hg(NO3)2⋅xH2O (Alfa Aesar), Pb(NO3)2 (Fisher), and Zn(NO3)2⋅6H2O (Aldrich) and metal perchlorates were obtained from VWR or Strem in ≥99% purity and used as received. All solutions were made up in deionized water (Milli-Q, Waters Corp.) of >18 MΩ⋅cm-1 resistivity, plus high-performance liquid chromatography grade methanol (MeOH) from Merck. Solutions were prepared in liquid chromatography/mass spectrometry grade MeOH and dimethyl sulfoxide (DMSO).

elements.content:
The C and N elemental compositions were measured with a CE Elantech model NC 2100CHN analyzer.

Synthesis of [Ag­(cdpa)­NO<sub>3</sub>] (<bold>1</bold>)

A total of 1 equiv of cdpa (33.3 mg, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 50:50 dichloromethane (DCM)/MeOH (6 mL) in a 30 mL sample vial. A solution of 1 equiv of AgNO3 (13.6 mg, 0.09 mmol) in 20% DCM/MeOH (6 mL) was carefully added to the cdpa solution. The solutions were allowed to slowly diffuse into one another and then allowed to slowly evaporate through a perforated parafilm. After considerable evaporation, pale-yellow crystals deposited on the bottom of the glass. The solution was filtered off under vacuum, and the crystals were air-dried. 1: pale-yellow crystals. Elem anal. Calcd for C24H23AgN4O7: C, 49.08; N, 9.54. Found: C, 49.19; N, 9.70.

elements.content: A total of 1 equiv of cdpa (33.3 mg, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 10% DMSO/MeOH (7 mL) in a 30 mL sample vial, into which a solution of 1 equiv of Pb­(NO3)2 (26.5 mg) dissolved in 2 mL of 10% DMSO/MeOH was added. The resulting solution in its vial was transferred to a larger jar, where it stood in about 5 mL of diethyl ether, and the lid of the jar was tightly closed. Diffusion of diethyl ether vapor into the solutions resulted in pale-yellow crystals. The solution was filtered off under vacuum, and the crystals were air-dried. Elem anal. Calcd for C24H23PbN5O10: C, 38.50; N, 9.35. Found: C, 38.38; N, 9.15.

elements.content: A total of 1 equiv of cdpa (33.3 mg, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 20% DMSO/MeOH (5 mL) in a 30 mL sample vial, into which a solution of 1 equiv of CdCl2·2.5H2O (18.2 mg) in MeOH (3 mL) was added. Use of the diethyl ether diffusion technique, as described for 2, resulted in pale-yellow crystals, which were filtered off under vacuum and air-dried. Analysis of the bulk product proved problematic. Repeated syntheses (twice) and elemental analyses (four times) consistently gave results that fitted the product plus a H2O molecule (calculated results are given in parentheses below). A mass spectrum did not give the molecular ion for the complex but only the free ligand plus other fragments. It is believed that the structure refers to a minority product crystal that had no H2O molecule in the lattice. Elem anal. Calcd for C24H23CdCl2N3O4 (H2O): C, 47.98 (46.58); N, 6.99 (6.79). Found: C, 46.44; N, 6.33.

Synthesis of [Cd(cdpa)2H2O](NO3)2 (5)

A total of 1 equiv of cdpa (33.3 mg, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 20% DMSO/MeOH (5 mL) in a 30 mL sample vial, into which a solution of 1 equiv of Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O (24.6 mg) in 20% DMSO/MeOH (4 mL) was added. Use of the diethyl ether diffusion technique, as described for 2, resulted in pale-yellow crystals, which were filtered off under vacuum and air-dried. Elem anal. Calcd for C48H46CdN8O14(H2O): C, 52.92; N, 10.29. Found: C, 52.28; N, 10.17.

elements.content: A Bruker D8-GADDS X-ray (three-circle) diffractometer was employed for crystal screening, unit cell determination, and data collection for structures 1–6. The structures were solved by direct methods and refined to convergence. Details of the structure determination are given in , and crystal coordinates and details of the structure determination of 1–6 have been deposited with the CSD (Cambridge Structural Database; see also the Supporting Information). A selection of bond lengths and angles for 1–6 are given in –. The structures of 1–6 are shown in –.

Excitation–emission matrix fluorescence properties were determined on a Jobin Yvon SPEX Fluoromax-3 scanning fluorimeter equipped with a 150 W xenon arc lamp and a R928P detector. The instrument was configured to collect the signal in ratio mode with a dark offset using 5 nm band passes on both the excitation and emission monochromators. Replicate scans were generally within 5% agreement in terms of the intensity and within band-pass resolution in terms of the peak location. The fluorescence of the cdpa solutions was recorded in 50% MeOH/H2O.
elements.clean_text:
Fluorescence Measurements

Excitation-emission matrix fluorescence properties were determined on a Jobin Yvon SPEX Fluoromax-3 scanning fluorimeter equipped with a 150 W xenon arc lamp and a R928P detector. The instrument was configured to collect the signal in ratio mode with a dark offset using 5 nm band passes on both the excitation and emission monochromators. Replicate scans were generally within 5% agreement in terms of the intensity and within band-pass resolution in terms of the peak location. The fluorescence of the cdpa solutions was recorded in 50% MeOH/H2O.

elements.content: Modeling and DFT calculations were carried out using the program Spartan. The B3LYP exchange-correlation functional was used for all DFT calculations, the 6-31G* basis set was used for the main-group elements, and the Lanl2DZ effective core potential was used for the metal ions. The program Hyperchem, which allows for user-defined force constants, was used for molecular mechanics (MM) calculations.
elements.clean_text:
DFT Calculations

Modeling and DFT calculations were carried out using the program Spartan. The B3LYP exchange-correlation functional was used for all DFT calculations, the 6-31G* basis set was used for the main-group elements, and the Lanl2DZ effective core potential was used for the metal ions. The program Hyperchem, which allows for user-defined force constants, was used for molecular mechanics (MM) calculations.

elements.content: Studies of the complex formation of cdpa with a variety of metal ions in 50% MeOH/H2O were carried out by titrating 5 × 10–6 M solutions of cdpa at pH 6.4 (where the ligand is not protonated) with solutions of the metal ions to obtain limiting spectra corresponding to the fully formed mono ML complexes and to allow for the determination of log K values from variation of the fluorescence intensity as a function of the metal-ion concentration. pK a (protonation constant) values in 50% MeOH/H2O were determined by titrating 2 × 10–6 M solutions of cdpa with base between pH 2 and 10, following changes in the absorbance spectra as a function of the pH. The resulting variation in the absorbance or fluorescence intensity, depending on which type of spectroscopy was used to monitor the equilibria, was analyzed as a function of the metal-ion concentration or pH using Excel. The program HySS was used to model the equilibria and generate species distribution diagrams. UV–visible spectra were recorded using a Varian 300 Cary 1E UV–visible spectrophotometer controlled by Cary Win UV Scan Application, version 02.00(5), software. Fluorescence spectra were recorded as described above. A VWR sympHony SR60IC pH meter with a VWR sympHony gel epoxy semimicrocombination pH electrode was used for all pH readings, which were made in the external titration cell, with N2 bubbled through the cell to exclude O2 and CO2. The pH meter was calibrated using standard acid–base titration methods, in which E° for the cell was determined from a linear plot of E versus calculated pH.
elements.clean_text:
Formation Constants

Studies of the complex formation of cdpa with a variety of metal ions in 50% MeOH/H2O were carried out by titrating 5 × 10-6 M solutions of cdpa at pH 6.4 (where the ligand is not protonated) with solutions of the metal ions to obtain limiting spectra corresponding to the fully formed mono ML complexes and to allow for the determination of log K values from variation of the fluorescence intensity as a function of the metal-ion concentration. pK a (protonation constant) values in 50% MeOH/H2O were determined by titrating 2 × 10-6 M solutions of cdpa with base between pH 2 and 10, following changes in the absorbance spectra as a function of the pH. The resulting variation in the absorbance or fluorescence intensity, depending on which type of spectroscopy was used to monitor the equilibria, was analyzed as a function of the metal-ion concentration or pH using Excel. The program HySS  was used to model the equilibria and generate species distribution diagrams. UV-visible spectra were recorded using a Varian 300 Cary 1E UV-visible spectrophotometer controlled by Cary Win UV Scan Application, version 02.00(5), software. Fluorescence spectra were recorded as described above. A VWR sympHony SR60IC pH meter with a VWR sympHony gel epoxy semimicrocombination pH electrode was used for all pH readings, which were made in the external titration cell, with N2 bubbled through the cell to exclude O2 and CO2. The pH meter was calibrated using standard acid-base titration methods, in which E° for the cell was determined from a linear plot of E versus calculated pH.

elements.content: In a are shown the fluorescence spectra of the adpa complexes with a selection of metal ions and in b the fluorescence spectra of the cdpa complexes with the same metal ions, all in 50% MeOH/H2O. It should be noted that these are the spectra of 5 × 10–6 M cdpa or adpa with a sufficient excess of metal ion in solution to ensure complete formation of the complex. The spectra reported for cdpa complexes by Lim and Bruckner refer to 1:1 metal/cdpa mixtures and so may not reflect the spectra of the fully formed complexes. What one sees in a is that, with the more strongly π-contacting anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa, the fluorescence is strongly quenched by all of the metal ions except ZnII and CdII. The fluorescence of the CdII(adpa) complex is weaker than that of the ZnII(adpa) complex, which was suggested to occur because the CdII(adpa) complex exists in solution as a mixture of π-contacted (weakly fluorescent) and non-π-contacted (strongly fluorescent) forms. Turning the attention to b, one sees that the CdII(cdpa) complex fluoresces virtually as strongly as does the ZnII(cdpa) complex. This would be exactly as predicted by the π-contact model of fluorescence in PET sensors, if the weakly π-contacting coumarin fluorophore of the cdpa sensor does not form π contacts in solution with either the ZnII or CdII(cdpa) complex.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Fluorescence of cdpa Complexes

In a are shown the fluorescence spectra of the adpa complexes with a selection of metal ions and in b the fluorescence spectra of the cdpa complexes with the same metal ions, all in 50% MeOH/H2O. It should be noted that these are the spectra of 5 × 10-6 M cdpa or adpa with a sufficient excess of metal ion in solution to ensure complete formation of the complex. The spectra reported for cdpa complexes by Lim and Bruckner refer to 1:1 metal/cdpa mixtures and so may not reflect the spectra of the fully formed complexes. What one sees in a is that, with the more strongly π-contacting anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa, the fluorescence is strongly quenched by all of the metal ions except ZnII and CdII. The fluorescence of the CdII(adpa) complex is weaker than that of the ZnII(adpa) complex, which was suggested to occur because the CdII(adpa) complex exists in solution as a mixture of π-contacted (weakly fluorescent) and non-π-contacted (strongly fluorescent) forms. Turning the attention to b, one sees that the CdII(cdpa) complex fluoresces virtually as strongly as does the ZnII(cdpa) complex. This would be exactly as predicted by the π-contact model of fluorescence in PET sensors, if the weakly π-contacting coumarin fluorophore of the cdpa sensor does not form π contacts in solution with either the ZnII or CdII(cdpa) complex.

elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of the complexes of a selection of metal ions with adpa (5 × 10–6 M) in 50% MeOH/H2O. Note that nearly all of the metal ions quench the fluorescence of adpa, with only ZnII showing a strong CHEF effect and CdII a somewhat weaker CHEF effect. (b) Fluorescence spectra of the complexes of a selection of metal ions with cdpa (5 × 10–6 M) in 50% MeOH/H2O. Now ZnII and CdII show nearly identical CHEF effects, with PbII and HgII showing weaker CHEF effects. Only AgI of the diamagnetic metal ions quenches the fluorescence of cdpa, and only AgI is shown here to form a π contact with cdpa. In each case, the spectrum of the complex is that obtained as a limiting spectrum when a sufficient concentration of the metal ion had been added to ensure complete formation of the complex.
elements.clean_text: 3  (a) Fluorescence spectra of the complexes of a selection of metal ions with adpa (5 × 10-6 M) in 50% MeOH/H2O. Note that nearly all of the metal ions quench the fluorescence of adpa, with only ZnII showing a strong CHEF effect and CdII a somewhat weaker CHEF effect. (b) Fluorescence spectra of the complexes of a selection of metal ions with cdpa (5 × 10-6 M) in 50% MeOH/H2O. Now ZnII and CdII show nearly identical CHEF effects, with PbII and HgII showing weaker CHEF effects. Only AgI of the diamagnetic metal ions quenches the fluorescence of cdpa, and only AgI is shown here to form a π contact with cdpa. In each case, the spectrum of the complex is that obtained as a limiting spectrum when a sufficient concentration of the metal ion had been added to ensure complete formation of the complex.

elements.content: One sees further in b that the PbII(cdpa) complex now shows a moderately strong CHEF effect, whereas the PbII(adpa) complex does not. Similarly, HgII in its cdpa complex shows a modest CHEF effect, which is not observed in the adpa complex. The powerfully π-contacting AgI ion completely quenches the fluorescence of both cdpa and adpa, as would be expected. One notes that the paramagnetic CuII and NiII ions almost completely quench the fluorescence of both adpa and cdpa, which is expected because the redox mechanisms involved do not appear to require the formation of a π contact.
elements.clean_text: One sees further in b that the PbII(cdpa) complex now shows a moderately strong CHEF effect, whereas the PbII(adpa) complex does not. Similarly, HgII in its cdpa complex shows a modest CHEF effect, which is not observed in the adpa complex. The powerfully π-contacting AgI ion completely quenches the fluorescence of both cdpa and adpa, as would be expected. One notes that the paramagnetic CuII and NiII ions almost completely quench the fluorescence of both adpa and cdpa, which is expected because the redox mechanisms involved do not appear to require the formation of a π contact.

elements.content: If the CdII(cdpa) complex is not present in significant proportion as a π-contacted form, then one predicts that, because there is little of the form containing fluorescence-quenching π contacts to be broken by coordinated anions such as Cl–, the fluorescence intensity of the fully formed non-π-contacted CdII(cdpa) complex will not be much affected by added Cl–. This is what is found, as shown in a,b. In a is shown the response of the fully formed CdII(adpa) complex to added Cl– ion. One sees a large shift in the fluorescence peak maximum, which would allow for ratiometric sensing of Cl–, and an increase in the fluorescence intensity. In contrast, in b, for the CdII(cdpa) complex, the addition of Cl– ion has little effect on the fluorescence of the complex. The small increase in the fluorescence intensity probably reflects driving of the equilibrium toward the complete formation of [Cd­(cdpa)­Cl]+ at high Cl– concentration according to , eliminating what small percentage of the CdII(cdpa) complex that might be π-contacted: Cd 2 + + cdpa + Cl − ⇆ [ Cd ( cdpa ) Cl ] +

This is what is found, as shown in a,b. In a is shown the response of the fully formed CdII(adpa) complex to added Cl- ion. One sees a large shift in the fluorescence peak maximum, which would allow for ratiometric sensing of Cl-, and an increase in the fluorescence intensity. In contrast, in b, for the CdII(cdpa) complex, the addition of Cl- ion has little effect on the fluorescence of the complex. The small increase in the fluorescence intensity probably reflects driving of the equilibrium toward the complete formation of [Cd(cdpa)Cl]+ at high Cl- concentration according to , eliminating what small percentage of the CdII(cdpa) complex that might be π-contacted: 1      Cd   2 +   + cdpa +   Cl   -   ⇆   [ Cd  ( cdpa )  Cl ]   +

(b) Fluorescence spectra of the CdII(cdpa) complex (5 × 10–6 M) in 50% MeOH/H2O titrated with NaCl. Note that sufficient excess of Cd2+ was added to ensure complete formation of the complex in both cases.

elements.content:
The point of interest is whether the crystal structures of the cdpa complexes support the π-contact model of fluorescence in PET sensors.

Structure of <bold>1</bold>

The structure of 1 is seen in , and bond lengths and angles of interest for 1 are given in . The Ag is coordinated in the more usual mer (meridional) fashion to the three N donors of the cdpa ligand. There are short Ag–N bonds to the two sp2-hybridized N donors of the pyridyl groups of the ligand, averaging 2.26 Å, with a long Ag–N bond of 2.679 Å to the central sp3-hybridized N donor of the ligand. The Ag–O bonds to a chelating nitrate are 2.412 and 2.705 Å. This type of structure is typical of the heavier d10 metal ions, with two short bonds to the two sp2-hybridized N donors, coordinated at roughly 180° to each other, with longer bonds to the remaining donor atoms. Of particular interest is the presence of two π contacts between the AgI ion and the dimethoxycoumarin fluorophore, of 3.083 and 3.095 Å. The structure of the AgI(cdpa) complex strongly resembles that of the AgI(adpa) complex, except that the latter has a η1 contact with the anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa, with an Ag···C distance of 3.016 Å, whereas the AgI ion in its cdpa complex has a η2 π contact. The presence of π contacts between the coordinated AgI and the fluorophore of cdpa is consistent with the π-contact model of quenching of the fluorescence, in that coordination of AgI to cdpa leads to strong quenching of the fluorescence, as also occurs with the adpa complex, where an Ag···C π contact is present. One has to bear in mind, of course, that the long Ag–N bond to the sp3-hybridized N donor of cdpa might also contribute to quenching of the fluorescence by a persistent PET effect.

The structure of 2 is seen in , and bond lengths and angles of interest for 2 are given in . What is of particular importance in 2 is that the dimethoxycoumarin fluorophore does not form a π contact with the PbII ion in its cdpa complex, in agreement with the fact that PbII shows a CHEF effect with cdpa, as seen in . In contrast, PbII forms a π contact with the anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa and correspondingly strongly quenches the fluorescence of adpa. In 2, there are Pb–N bonds to the two sp2-hybridized N donors of the pyridyl groups of cdpa of 2.519 and 2.616 Å, with a Pb–N bond of 2.614 Å to the central sp3-hybridized N donor of the ligand. The cdpa ligand is coordinated to the PbII ion in a less usual fac (facial) manner, which was also found for the adpa complex: fac coordination allows all three N donors to coordinate near the favored coordination site opposite the inert pair of electrons of the PbII ion, the antipodal site. The Pb ion forms four Pb–O bonds to two chelating nitrates with lengths ranging from 2.609 to 3.138 Å and also forms two PbO bonds to a bridging nitrate from an adjacent Pb with lengths of 2.816 and 2.836 Å. The position of a stereochemically active lone pair on the PbII ion is suggested by a gap in the coordination geometry roughly opposite N2, the gap of which is surrounded by long Pb–O bonds ranging from 2.836 to 3.138 Å. The Pb–N bonds, which are closer to the antipodal site, are, as noted above, all much shorter, ranging from 2.519 to 2.616 Å.

The structure of 3 is seen in a, and bond lengths and angles of interest for 3 are given in . The Zn is coordinated in a mer fashion to the three N donors of the cdpa ligand with Zn–N bonds to the two sp2-hybridized N donors of the pyridyl groups of the ligand of 2.025 and 2.022 Å and with a Zn–N bond of 2.333 Å to the central sp3-hybridized N donor of the ligand. The Zn forms three Zn–O bonds to one chelating and one nonchelating nitrate, with lengths ranging from 2.057 to 2.442 Å. The Zn···O6 contact, indicated as a dashed bond in a, is rather long at 2.854 Å, which appears to be caused by steric interaction with the H atoms on the methylene linker holding the fluorophore in place. The dimethoxycoumarin fluorophore does not form a π contact with the ZnII ion in its cdpa complex, in agreement with the fact that ZnII shows a strong CHEF effect with cdpa in . ZnII is a weak π-contacter, so this is as expected: ZnII also does not form a π contact with the anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa and so also shows a strong CHEF effect with adpa.

The crystal packing of 3 is of some interest, as seen in b: the structure illustrates some other weak interactions that are important in structural chemistry, namely, π stacking of aromatic rings on each other and H···C­(aromatic) π contacts, the structural features of which are observed in structures 1–6. The unit cell of 3 is shown with two [Zn­(cdpa)­(NO3)2] individuals held together by π stacking. The two dimethoxycoumarin fluorophores have best-fit planes separated by a C···C distance of 3.445 Å, which is typical for π stacking of aromatic groups. The structure is held together by columns of dimethoxycoumarin fluorophores from one row of [Zn­(cdpa)­(NO3)2] individuals π-stacked on columns of dimethoxycoumarin fluorophores from an opposing row of [Zn­(cdpa)­(NO3)2] individuals. What may also be involved in controlling the structure of the crystal are H···C­(aromatic) π contacts between H atoms on the methoxy groups of the fluorophores and C atoms from the pyridyl groups of the cdpa ligand. These H···C distances are (b) 2.860 Å, somewhat less than the sum of the van der Waals radii of C and H. Such H···C­(aromatic) π contacts appear to be important in biology, where, for example, they may control molecular recognition of the carbohydrate groups responsible for determining A, B, and O blood group types.

elements.content: The structure of 4 is seen in , and bond lengths and angles of interest for 4 are given in . The complex is a dimer with the two CdII ions held together by two bridging chloride ions. Each CdII is 6-coordinate, with three Cd–N bonds to cdpa ranging from 2.365 to 2.487 Å and three Cd–Cl bonds ranging from 2.479 to 2.660 Å. There are no π contacts between the CdII ions and the fluorophores of the cdpa ligands present, in accordance with the observation that CdII shows () a strong CHEF effect in solution with cdpa. One can argue, of course, that the chlorides coordinated to the CdII ions in 4 completely satisfy the most common coordination number of 6 found in the CSD for CdII complexes and so sterically preclude the formation of a π contact. Interestingly, 4 strongly resembles one of the complex species present in the corresponding structure of the adpa complex, which is also a chloride-bridged dimer with no π contacts present. The latter CdII(adpa) complex unit cell also contains a monomeric species, [Cd­(adpa)­Cl2], with a π-contacted anthracenyl fluorophore, which strongly supports the suggestion that the CdII can exist as both π-contacted and non-π-contacted species. It may be that the lack of any π-contacted form in the unit cell of 4 is indicative of the weaker π-contacting ability of the dimethoxycoumarin fluorophore of cdpa compared to the anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa because the adpa CdCl2 structure contains forms with and without π contacts, while the cdpa CdCl2 structure (4) contains only a non-π-contacted form.

The structure of 5 is seen in , and bond lengths and angles of interest for 5 are given in . The CdII ion in 5 is 7-coordinate, having two cdpa ligands coordinated to the CdII ion (average Cd–N = 2.421 Å), plus a H2O molecule, with Cd–O = 2.329 Å. A coordination number of 7 is less common for CdII: a search of the CSD yields 488 structures of CdII with six N donors coordinated to the CdII ion and a maximum coordination number of 6. On the other hand, there are only 10 structures of CdII with six N donors and a seventh donor atom that is an O. One of these is the CdII(dpa)2 complex, where the unit cell contains one 6-coordinate CdII(dpa)2 complex and a second 7-coordinate CdII(dpa)2 individual that has a unidentate nitrate bound to the Cd. It thus appears that it is not energetically too unfavorable for the CdII ion to achieve an N6O donor set with two dpa-type ligands such as cdpa bound to CdII. In order to gain some insight into why the CdII ion in 5 adopts a 7-coordinate structure, incorporating a H2O molecule, MM calculations were carried out using the program HyperChem. It was found that MM calculations reproduced the structure of 5 quite well, with the metal ion modeled with a “points on a sphere” approach, so that the metal ion was not constrained to any particular geometry. When the H2O molecule was removed and the structure energy minimized, a cavity remained, formed by the two fluorophores arching over the site where the H2O molecule could be coordinated. It thus appears that coordination of a H2O molecule to the CdII ion in the cdpa bis-complex might be promoted by the architecture of the ligand, which provides a cage-type structure that creates a space in which the H2O molecule can coordinate to the CdII ion, as shown in .

The structure of 5 was somewhat unexpected because the crystals were grown with a 1:1 Cd/cdpa ratio. This has been found in our research to occur where bulky ligands such as DPP, rather hydrophobic on what will be the outside of the complex, are used for crystal growing in a more polar solvent such as MeOH. The 1:1 M/L mixtures produce crystals containing what must be the less soluble bis-complexes of 2,9-di­(pyrid-2-yl)-1,10-phenanthroline (DPP) with both ZnII and CdII.

This has been found in our research to occur where bulky ligands such as DPP, rather hydrophobic on what will be the outside of the complex, are used for crystal growing in a more polar solvent such as MeOH. elements.content: Solutions that are 1:1 in metal ions and ligands such as adpa and cdpa are used in crystal-growing experiments, or in fluorescence studies, with the belief that one has only the ML complex present in solution. The structure of 5 raises the question of what species are actually present in a 1:1 solution of adpa or cdpa with a metal ion. An indication of this can be gained from the log K 1 and log K 2 values available for a range of metal ions with the dpa ligand in aqueous solution, as seen in . The log K 1 and log K 2 values reported by Anderegg et al. for dpa complexes were used in the species distribution modeling program HySS to calculate the percent of total CdII in a 1:1 solution of CdII and dpa (2 × 10–5 M) that would be present as ML and ML2 complexes. One sees in that this is strongly dependent on log (K 1/K 2). If log (K 1/K 2) is close to 3 or above, the percentage of M present as ML2 is very small. Thus, for metal ions such as ZnII, PbII, and AgI, log (K 1/K 2) for dpa is close to 3, and so the concentration of ML2 species in a 1:1 M/dpa solution will be very low, which should also be the case for the cdpa complexes, so that crystallization produces the ML species. For CdII, log (K 1/K 2) for the dpa complex is low at only 1.03, and there should be some 13.9% of the total CdII present as the ML2 complex in a 1:1 CdII(dpa) solution. A similar result for CdII with cdpa would account for crystallization of the cdpa bis-complex from a 1:1 CdII(cdpa) solution.

elements.content: The structure of 6 is shown as a space-filling drawing in , and bond lengths and angles of interest for 6 are given in . 6 is isomorphous with 5. A comparison of the bond lengths and angles in and shows how similar the two complexes are: the Cd–N bond lengths, for example, average 2.411 Å, while the Hg–N bond lengths average 2.441 Å. The slightly longer Hg–N bonds are in accordance with the greater ionic radius for HgII of 1.02 Å for 6-coordination compared to 0.96 Å for CdII. The structure of 6 here illustrates an important fact about the structure of HgII complexes. When the set of donor atoms bound to HgII contains some donor atoms producing M–L bonds of high covalence and others that are more ionic, there is usually distortion to produce a quasi-linear structure as discussed above. When all six donor atoms form Hg–L bonds of equally high covalence, then a more regular structure is formed with all Hg–L bonds of very similar length and also similar to the CdII analogue. Thus, for example, the six M–N bonds in the dpa bis-complexes of HgII are of similar length and average 2.416 ± 0.075 Å compared to 2.360 ± 0.016 Å in the CdII analogue: in the HgII(9-ane-S3)2 complex, the six Hg–S bonds are similar in length and average 2.682 Å, ± 0.023 Å while in the CdII analogue, the Cd–S bonds average 2.658 ± 0.004 Å. It is only with six covalently bound donor atoms bound to both HgII and CdII that the usual structural similarity between complexes of pairs of the heavier metal ions in the same group in the d-block elements, such as PdII and PtII, or RhIII and IrIII, becomes apparent with CdII and HgII.

These are results obtained here for HgII with cdpa in 50% MeOH/H2O. For the HgII(dpa) complex, log K 1 has not been reported, with only log β2 given as 22.2. ,

The very high percentage of HgII left uncomplexed by cdpa is present as Hg­(OH)2 in solution, which results from the equilibrium 2Hg­(cdpa)2+ + 2OH– ⇆ Hg­(cdpa)2 2+ + Hg­(OH)2 at pH 7.0. The latter equilibrium accounts for the very small percentage of HgII present as the mono-complex Hg­(cdpa)2+. A value of log β2 = 21.6 for formation of the Hg­(OH)2 species in a 50% MeOH/H2O solution was used in the calculations on the HgII(cdpa) system, the determination of which will be reported elsewhere.

The fluorophores in structures 5 and 6 form no π contacts with either CdII or HgII in their cdpa bis-complexes: the π-contact hypothesis concerning quenching of the fluorescence of PET sensors thus predicts that both of these complexes should fluoresce strongly in solution. In the case of the CdII(cdpa) mono-complex, the weakly π-contacting CdII should not form a strong π contact with the weakly π-contacting fluorophore. In contrast, HgII is a strong π-contacter, being between PbII and AgI in the π-contacting strength series discussed above. PbII shows a moderately strong CHEF effect with cdpa, as seen in b, which is ascribed to the PbII(cdpa) complex existing in solution as an equilibrium mixture of π-contacted (weakly fluorescent) and non-π-contacted (strongly fluorescent) species. One would thus expect HgII to be better at forming π contacts than PbII, and so in the mono-complex, it shows weaker fluorescence than PbII, as seen in b.

elements.content: The formation constants determined here in 50% MeOH/H2O for cdpa complexes with a selection of metal ions are seen in . The protonation constants reported were determined preferentially by absorbance spectroscopy: it was found that variation of the fluorescence spectral intensities with the pH that might be used for pK a analysis was somewhat erratic, as can occur with hydrogen-bonding structures that affect the intensity in a solvent such as 50% MeOH/H2O. The formation constants for the metal cdpa complexes were determined as reported previously for adpa by titration of a 5 × 10–6 M cdpa solution with a metal-ion solution, with monitoring of the equilibrium by measurement of the fluorescence spectra: the intensity of these spectra were much better behaved than those related to the pK a determination. Also shown in for comparison are the formation constants for dpa (in aqueous solution) and adpa (in 50% MeOH/H2O) complexes. The fact that the log K 1 values for the dpa complexes are reported in an aqueous solution should not make a great difference because it has been found that log K 1 values for 50% MeOH/H2O and H2O are quite similar. One sees that the order of stability for most metal ions with the three ligands is dpa > adpa > cdpa. This might relate to some extent to the greater basicity of the central N donor of each ligand because the pK a values vary in the same order. An exception is AgI, where it is found that the adpa complex is considerably more stable than the dpa complex, which is slightly more stable than the cdpa complex. One would suggest that this reflects the strength of the π contact formed by AgI with the anthracenyl fluorophore, which overrides the lower basicity of the central N of adpa. Although log K 1 for the cdpa complex of AgI is slightly less than log K 1 for the dpa complex, this is in contrast to the large drop in log K 1 from the dpa to cdpa complex for all of the other metal ions, suggesting again a degree of stabilization of the AgI(cdpa) complex by the formation of a π contact with the fluorophore of cdpa. No log K 1 value for HgII with dpa is available, but one notes the larger drop in log K 1 from the adpa to cdpa complex, suggesting that the HgII(adpa) complex is stabilized by a strong π contact.

No log K 1 value for HgII with dpa is available, but one notes the larger drop in log K 1 from the adpa to cdpa complex, suggesting that the HgII(adpa) complex is stabilized by a strong π contact.

From ref .

The formation constants of HgII with cdpa in 50% MeOH/H2O were measured by monitoring the fluorescence intensity of a 5 × 10–6 M solution of both Hg­(ClO4)2 and cdpa over the pH range 2–12. Variation of the peak intensity at five different wavelengths with pH is seen in . The intensity is quite low in the pH range 2–4, it rises strongly to pH 6, and then drops down again to pH 8.0. One can understand this behavior from the species distribution diagram in . The higher intensity fluorescence of the HgII(cdpa) system between pH 4 and 8 appears to correspond to the presence of the HgII(cdpa) complex. One would expect a higher fluorescence intensity for this species because structure 6 shows that both fluorophores are not π-contacted with the HgII ion, and there are no long Hg–N bonds in the structure that might lead to a PET effect that quenches the fluorescence. The species distribution diagram in shows how the species present in a 1:1 HgII(cdpa) solution at a typical pH of 7.0 might be quite different from an assumption that in such a 1:1 solution one has mainly the HgII(cdpa) monospecies present. A more complete analysis of species present in solutions used for studying the fluorescent sensing of metal ions can make such studies much more informative and valuable in developing theories of how the CHEF effect operate in such systems.

elements.content: The presence of η2 π contacts in the AgI(cdpa) complex, and a η1 π contact in the AgI(adpa) complex, raises the question of what patterns of hapticity might exist for π contacts formed by AgI and other types of metal ions. The interest is to obtain a broad picture of what types of metal ions prefer low hapticities such as η1 or η2, on the one hand, and what types prefer high hapticities such as η6, on the other hand. After examination of a large number of structures in the CSD, a difference of more than 0.2 Å between the shortest contact present, and its adjacent contacts, was used to define a η1 π contact. This choice is not critical because most contacts assigned as η1 have much larger differences than the one with adjacent contacts: for example, the π contact of 3.018 Å in the AgI(adpa) complex, identified as being a η1 π contact, has Ag···C contacts on either side of it of 3.537 and 3.461 Å. One defines a η2 π contact as having the shortest two adjacent contacts present, differing by no more than 0.2 Å from each other but being at least 0.2 Å shorter than any adjacent contacts present. Again, this does not appear to be a critical choice: in the AgI(cdpa) complex reported here, as a typical example, identified as having a η2 π contact, the two Ag···C η2 π contacts are 3.083 and 3.095 Å, while the two Ag···C contacts on either side of the two η2 π contacts are 3.724 and 3.750 Å. Contacts of hapticity η3–η5 seemed uncommon with the metal ions examined here and so were not considered further. A η6 set of π contacts was defined as having all six contacts within 0.5 Å of each other. Again, the latter choice does not appear to be crucial because, in most cases identified as η6 π contacts, the differences are much smaller than that. The definition of hapticity adopted here allows for easy searching of the CSD and transfer of the results into the Excel program, where automated assignment of the hapticity can be carried out.
elements.clean_text:
Patterns of Hapticity for π Contacts of Different Metal Ions

The presence of η2 π contacts in the AgI(cdpa) complex, and a η1 π contact in the AgI(adpa) complex, raises the question of what patterns of hapticity might exist for π contacts formed by AgI and other types of metal ions. The interest is to obtain a broad picture of what types of metal ions prefer low hapticities such as η1 or η2, on the one hand, and what types prefer high hapticities such as η6, on the other hand. After examination of a large number of structures in the CSD, a difference of more than 0.2 Å between the shortest contact present, and its adjacent contacts, was used to define a η1 π contact. This choice is not critical because most contacts assigned as η1 have much larger differences than the one with adjacent contacts: for example, the π contact of 3.018 Å in the AgI(adpa) complex, identified as being a η1 π contact, has Ag⋅⋅⋅C contacts on either side of it of 3.537 and 3.461 Å. One defines a η2 π contact as having the shortest two adjacent contacts present, differing by no more than 0.2 Å from each other but being at least 0.2 Å shorter than any adjacent contacts present. Again, this does not appear to be a critical choice: in the AgI(cdpa) complex reported here, as a typical example, identified as having a η2 π contact, the two Ag⋅⋅⋅C η2 π contacts are 3.083 and 3.095 Å, while the two Ag⋅⋅⋅C contacts on either side of the two η2 π contacts are 3.724 and 3.750 Å. Contacts of hapticity η3-η5 seemed uncommon with the metal ions examined here and so were not considered further. A η6 set of π contacts was defined as having all six contacts within 0.5 Å of each other. Again, the latter choice does not appear to be crucial because, in most cases identified as η6 π contacts, the differences are much smaller than that. The definition of hapticity adopted here allows for easy searching of the CSD and transfer of the results into the Excel program, where automated assignment of the hapticity can be carried out.

elements.content: The CSD was searched to determine the hapticty of a selection of metal ions when bound to benzene or simple aromatics such as xylenes or naphthalene. This was done to avoid more sterically constraining situations, where the observed hapticity may derive from the steric properties of a ligand with additional donor groups apart from the π-contacting aromatic. For example, PbII forms a η1 π contact in its adpa complex, even though with less sterically constraining aromatics such as xylenes it always forms η6 π contacts, as seen in . In are shown the hapticities observed in the CSD for a selection of metal ions with simple aromatics. It is apparent that d10 metal ions such as CuI, AgI, AuI, ZnII, CdII, and HgII form π contacts that, in the absence of additional constraining factors, are nearly always η1 or η2. More ionically bound metal ions, such as NaI, KI, BaII, LaIII, or ThIV, are nearly always η6 π-contacted with simple aromatics. It appears that this arises from the more ionic bonding of the latter ions being electrostatically attracted to the general cloud of electron density present in the π system, whereas the more covalently bound d10 metal ions form more directed bonds to one or two C atoms, which may involve a σ-bonding component to the interaction. One notes that square-planar or tetragonally distorted metal ions such as CuII and PdII in appear to prefer η1 π contacts, which may simply be due to the limited space available for the formation of π contacts on the axial coordination sites of these metal ions.

The hapticity is defined as follows: η1, shortest contact shorter than any other contact by at least 0.2 Å; η2, two shortest contacts within 0.2 Å of each other and shorter than any other contacts by at least 0.2 Å; η3, three shortest contacts within 0.2 Å of each other and shorter than any other contacts by at least 0.2 Å; η6, all six contacts within 0.5 Å of each other.

Bold type indicates predominant hapticities of each metal ion.

A further group of predominately η6 π-contacted metal ions in the absence of sterically constraining factors appears from to be the d10s2 metal ions such as TlI, PbII, and BiIII. For these metal ions, the structures suggest that the π-contacted aromatic rings coordinate near the site of the “inert pair” of electrons on the metal ion. One assigns the position of the inert pair by examining the structure for a “gap” in the coordination sphere and/or longer M–L bonds near the proposed site of the lone pair and shorter M–L bonds opposite the site. The bonds near the lone pair on PbII are very long, and it appears that these probably are also ionic and rather weakly directional and thus favor η6 contacts.

For these metal ions, the structures suggest that the π-contacted aromatic rings coordinate near the site of the "inert pair" of electrons on the metal ion. One assigns the position of the inert pair by examining the structure for a "gap" in the coordination sphere and/or longer M-L bonds near the proposed site of the lone pair and shorter M-L bonds opposite the site. The bonds near the lone pair on PbII are very long, and it appears that these probably are also ionic and rather weakly directional and thus favor η6 contacts.

elements.content: Effects of the formation of π contacts on the structures of aromatic rings by the metal ions considered here appear to be minimal, as would be expected for fairly weak interactions. An important parameter is the value of the C···C–H angle, involving the p-C atom across the aromatic ring from the ipso-C atom, where the π contact is formed, and the H atom attached to the ipso-C atom. Ideally, this angle should be 180°, but with formation of a π contact, the H atom may be bent away from the π-contacting metal ion, and the angle is decreased, decreasing more with increasing strength of the π contact. With strong π contacts, such as η1 Hg···C π contacts of as short as 2.269 Å, the C···C–H angle across the aromatic ring can be as little as 144.9° instead of the expected 180°, with the H atom on the ipso-C atom strongly bent away from the π-contacting Hg atom. The AgI ion forms numerous fairly short Ag···C π contacts close to 2.49 Å, where the C···C–H angle across the aromatic ring is typically decreased by only about 2–3° compared to the expected value for the angle of 180°. In the mercury­(II) dichloride complex of adpa, with a Hg···C π contact of 3.215 Å, the C···C–H angle is 175.7°, with the ipso-H atom bent away from the π-contacting Hg atom. In the AgI complexes of adpa and cdpa, the decreases in the C···C–H angles are small, at 1.8° for the adpa complex and 0.6° for the cdpa complex, consistent with the idea that the π contacts are rather weak.

Ideally, this angle should be 180°, but with formation of a π contact, the H atom may be bent away from the π-contacting metal ion, and the angle is decreased, decreasing more with increasing strength of the π contact. With strong π contacts, such as η1 Hg⋅⋅⋅C π contacts of as short as 2.269 Å, the C⋅⋅⋅C-H angle across the aromatic ring can be as little as 144.9° instead of the expected 180°, with the H atom on the ipso-C atom strongly bent away from the π-contacting Hg atom. The AgI ion forms numerous fairly short Ag⋅⋅⋅C π contacts close to 2.49 Å, where the C⋅⋅⋅C-H angle across the aromatic ring is typically decreased by only about 2-3° compared to the expected value for the angle of 180°. In the mercury(II) dichloride complex of adpa, with a Hg⋅⋅⋅C π contact of 3.215 Å, the C⋅⋅⋅C-H angle is 175.7°, with the ipso-H atom bent away from the π-contacting Hg atom. In the AgI complexes of adpa and cdpa, the decreases in the C⋅⋅⋅C-H angles are small, at 1.8° for the adpa complex and 0.6° for the cdpa complex, consistent with the idea that the π contacts are rather weak.

elements.content: (1) The order of π-contacting ability of the metal ions considered here appears to be ZnII ≪ CdII < PbII < HgII < PdII ≈ CuII ≈ AgI. The coumarin fluorophore cdpa is suggested by electrostatic potential maps to be a weaker M···C π contacter than the anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa: the order of ability to produce a CHEF effect with cdpa is ZnII ≈ CdII > PbII > HgII ≫ AgI (no CHEF effect) ≈ CuII ≈ NiII compared to the order for adpa of ZnII > CdII ≫ PbII (no CHEF effect) ≈ HgII ≈ AgI ≈ CuII ≈ NiII. With both cdpa and adpa, the paramagnetic CuII and NiII ions strongly quench the fluorescence, in line with a redox mechanism of quenching that does not appear to require the formation of M···C π contacts. (2) Crystallographically, only the AgI(cdpa) complex (1) shows M···C π contacts, in agreement with the observation that AgI strongly quenches the fluorescence of cdpa, while the other diamagnetic metal ions show CHEF effects. Importantly, PbII (2) shows in the solid-state structure of its cdpa mono-complex no M···C π contacts with the fluorophore of cdpa, and also shows a CHEF effect. In contrast, the PbII(adpa) complex shows an M···C π contact and so shows no CHEF effect. (3) The observation of cdpa bis-complexes in 5 and 6 in spite of crystal growth from solutions that had 1:1 molar ratios of metal ion and cdpa raises the question of what species might be present in such solutions. It is clear that, if one wishes to understand the CHEF effect in fluorescent sensors for metal ions, it is important to establish that the complex in solution is completely formed and also to understand the speciation of the solution. One might otherwise, for example, conclude that a metal ion such as HgII showed no CHEF effect with the sensor, when, in fact, it had not formed a complex.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusions

(1) The order of π-contacting ability of the metal ions considered here appears to be ZnII ≪ CdII < PbII < HgII < PdII ~ CuII ~ AgI. The coumarin fluorophore cdpa is suggested by electrostatic potential maps to be a weaker M⋅⋅⋅C π contacter than the anthracenyl fluorophore of adpa: the order of ability to produce a CHEF effect with cdpa is ZnII ~ CdII > PbII > HgII ≫ AgI (no CHEF effect) ~ CuII ~ NiII compared to the order for adpa of ZnII > CdII ≫ PbII (no CHEF effect) ~ HgII ~ AgI ~ CuII ~ NiII. With both cdpa and adpa, the paramagnetic CuII and NiII ions strongly quench the fluorescence, in line with a redox mechanism of quenching that does not appear to require the formation of M⋅⋅⋅C π contacts. (2) Crystallographically, only the AgI(cdpa) complex (1) shows M⋅⋅⋅C π contacts, in agreement with the observation that AgI strongly quenches the fluorescence of cdpa, while the other diamagnetic metal ions show CHEF effects. Importantly, PbII (2) shows in the solid-state structure of its cdpa mono-complex no M⋅⋅⋅C π contacts with the fluorophore of cdpa, and also shows a CHEF effect. In contrast, the PbII(adpa) complex shows an M⋅⋅⋅C π contact and so shows no CHEF effect. (3) The observation of cdpa bis-complexes in 5 and 6 in spite of crystal growth from solutions that had 1:1 molar ratios of metal ion and cdpa raises the question of what species might be present in such solutions. It is clear that, if one wishes to understand the CHEF effect in fluorescent sensors for metal ions, it is important to establish that the complex in solution is completely formed and also to understand the speciation of the solution. One might otherwise, for example, conclude that a metal ion such as HgII showed no CHEF effect with the sensor, when, in fact, it had not formed a complex.

A total of 1 equiv of cdpa (33.3 mg, 0.08 mmol) was dissolved in 10% DMSO/MeOH (7 mL) in a 30 mL sample vial, into which a solution of 1 equiv of Pb­(NO3)2 (26.5 mg) dissolved in 2 mL of 10% DMSO/MeOH was added. The resulting solution in its vial was transferred to a larger jar, where it stood in about 5 mL of diethyl ether, and the lid of the jar was tightly closed. Diffusion of diethyl ether vapor into the solutions resulted in pale-yellow crystals. The solution was filtered off under vacuum, and the crystals were air-dried. Elem anal. Values of log <italic toggle="yes">K</italic> <sub>1</sub> and log <italic toggle="yes">K</italic> <sub>2</sub> for Dipicolylamine (dpa) Complexes, in Aqueous Solution,<named-content content-type="bibref-group"> <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref41"></xref>,<xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref42"></xref> </named-content> Showing the Percentage of Mono (ML) and Bis (ML<sub>2</sub>) Complexes Present for Each Metal Ion in a 1:1 Solution of the Metal Ion and dpa, Each 2 × 10<sup>–5</sup> M, at pH 7.0, As Calculated Using the Program <italic toggle="yes">HySS</italic> <xref ref-type="bibr" rid="ref30"></xref> metal ion NiII CuII AgI ZnII CdII HgII  PbII log K 1(dpa) 9.30 13.85 5.46 7.63 6.40 (11.1) 6.00 log K 2(dpa) 7.30 4.6 2.7 4.52 5.36 (8.5) 2.55 log (K 1/K 2) 2.00 9.3 2.8 3.11 1.04 (2.6) 3.45 % of M uncomplexed 0.4 0.001 46.0 5.6 25.2 (65.1) 28.4 % of M as ML 83.2 99.9 52.3 92.3 60.9 (0.2) 69.9 % of M as ML2 16.4 0.1 1.7 2.1 13.9 (34.7) 1.7

These are results obtained here for HgII with cdpa in 50% MeOH/H2O. For the HgII(dpa) complex, log K 1 has not been reported, with only log β2 given as 22.2. ,

The very high percentage of HgII left uncomplexed by cdpa is present as Hg­(OH)2 in solution, which results from the equilibrium 2Hg­(cdpa)2+ + 2OH– ⇆ Hg­(cdpa)2 2+ + Hg­(OH)2 at pH 7.0. The latter equilibrium accounts for the very small percentage of HgII present as the mono-complex Hg­(cdpa)2+. A value of log β2 = 21.6 for formation of the Hg­(OH)2 species in a 50% MeOH/H2O solution was used in the calculations on the HgII(cdpa) system, the determination of which will be reported elsewhere.

[^a]: The hapticity is defined as follows: η<sup>1</sup>, shortest contact shorter than any other contact by at least 0.2 Å; η<sup>2</sup>, two shortest contacts within 0.2 Å of each other and shorter than any other contacts by at least 0.2 Å; η<sup>3</sup>, three shortest contacts within 0.2 Å of each other and shorter than any other contacts by at least 0.2 Å; η<sup>6</sup>, all six contacts within 0.5 Å of each other.
[^b]: Bold type indicates predominant hapticities of each metal ion.

cln_elements.content: (a) Fluorescence spectra of the complexes of a selection of metal ions with adpa (5 × 10–6 M) in 50% MeOH/H2O. Note that nearly all of the metal ions quench the fluorescence of adpa, with only ZnII showing a strong CHEF effect and CdII a somewhat weaker CHEF effect. (b) Fluorescence spectra of the complexes of a selection of metal ions with cdpa (5 × 10–6 M) in 50% MeOH/H2O. Now ZnII and CdII show nearly identical CHEF effects, with PbII and HgII showing weaker CHEF effects. Only AgI of the diamagnetic metal ions quenches the fluorescence of cdpa, and only AgI is shown here to form a π contact with cdpa. In each case, the spectrum of the complex is that obtained as a limiting spectrum when a sufficient concentration of the metal ion had been added to ensure complete formation of the complex.
